tit.e: Isuien Garden (a kaiyushiki garden [Japanese style garden with a path around a central pond] in Nara City, Nara Prefecture)
Isuien Garden (a kaiyushiki garden [Japanese style garden with a path around a central pond] in Nara City, Nara Prefecture)

sen.j: 依水園（いすいえん）は奈良県奈良市にある回遊式庭園（日本庭園）。
sen.e: Isuien Garden is kaiyushiki garden (Japanese style garden with a path around a central pond) located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
Isuien Garden is kaiyushiki garden located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 前出補足を削除しました。
sen.e: Isuien Garden is kaiyushiki garden located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 国指定の名勝。
sen.e: It is a national-designated site of scenic beauty.
It is a national-designated site of scenic beauty.
It is a national-designated site of scenic beauty.

sen.j: 前園と後園の二つに分かれており、それぞれが異なった景観を見せる。
sen.e: It is divided into two, the front garden and the rear garden, each of which presents different landscape.
It is divided into two, the front garden and the rear garden, each of which presents different landscape.
It is divided into two, the front garden and the rear garden, each of which presents different landscape.

sen.j: 前園は寛文12年（1673年）に晒職人であった清須美道清の作庭で、茶室「三秀亭」がシンボル。
sen.e: The front garden was designed and landscaped by Michikiyo KIYOSUMI, a bleacher in 1673 and there is a tea house 'Sanshu-tei' which symbolizes the garden.
The front garden was designed and landscaped by Michikiyo KIYOSUMI, a bleacher in 1673 and there is a tea house 'Sanshu-tei' which symbolizes the garden.
The front garden was designed and landscaped by Michikiyo KIYOSUMI, a bleacher in 1673 and there is a tea house 'Sanshu-tei' which symbolizes the garden.

sen.j: 後園は明治時代に実業家関藤次郎が築いた築山式の池泉回遊式庭園で、作庭は裏千家十二世又妙斎宗室による。
sen.e: The rear garden is a Tsukiyama-style (a style of garden, arranged to show nature in miniature, with hills, ponds and streams) Chisen Kaiyu style garden (a style of Japanese garden with a path around a central pond and spring) established by Tojiro SEKI, a businessman in the Meiji period, which was landscaped by Soshitsu Yumyosai Urasenke school 12th.

The rear garden is a Tsukiyama-style (a style of garden, arranged to show nature in miniature, with hills, ponds and streams) Chisen Kaiyu style garden (a style of Japanese garden with a path around a central pond and spring) established by Tojiro SEKI, a businessman in the Meiji period, which was landscaped by Soshitsu Yumyosai, the 12th Urasenke school.

The rear garden is a Tsukiyama-style (a style of garden, arranged to show nature in miniature, with hills, ponds and streams) Chisen Kaiyu style garden (a style of Japanese garden with a path around a central pond and spring) established by Tojiro SEKI, a businessman in the Meiji period, which was landscaped by Soshitsu Yumyosai, the 12th Urasenke school.

sen.j: 寧楽の都をモチーフとし、若草山や東大寺南大門などを借景とする。
sen.e: The garden made Nara no miyako (Nara, the capital) a motif and was designed to benefit from its surrounding scenery including Mt. Wakakusa and Nandai-mon gate (the great south gate) of Todai-ji Temple.

The garden made Nara no miyako (Nara, the ancient capital) a motif and was designed to benefit from its surrounding scenery including Mt. Wakakusa and Nandai-mon Gate (the great south gate) of Todai-ji Temple.

The garden made Nara no miyako (Nara, the ancient capital) a motif and was designed to benefit from its surrounding scenery including Mt. Wakakusa and Nandai-mon Gate (the great south gate) of Todai-ji Temple.

sen.j: いずれも大和川支流吉城川（よしきがわ）の水を引いている。
sen.e: Both bring water from Yoshiki-gawa River, a tributary of Yamato-gawa River.
Both bring water from the Yoshiki-gawa River, a tributary of the Yamato-gawa River.
Both bring water from the Yoshiki-gawa River, a tributary of the Yamato-gawa River.

sen.j: 海運業で財を成した中村家が1939年に買い取り、前園と後園を合わせた形に整備した。
sen.e: The Nakamura family which made a fortune in the shipping business purchased the garden in 1939 and developed it to a combined form of the front and the rear gardens.
The Nakamura family which made a fortune in the shipping business purchased the garden in 1939 and developed it to a combined form of the front and the rear gardens.
The Nakamura family which made a fortune in the shipping business purchased the garden in 1939 and developed it to a combined form of the front and the rear gardens.

sen.j: 1969年には、中村家所蔵の美術品を展示するため、寧楽美術館を建設して一般公開している。
sen.e: In 1969, Neiraku Art Museum was constructed to exhibit the artworks collected by the Nakamura family and opened to the public.
In 1969, Neiraku Art Museum was constructed to exhibit the artworks collected by the Nakamura family and opened to the public.
In 1969, Neiraku Art Museum was constructed to exhibit the artworks collected by the Nakamura family and opened to the public.

sen.j: 名の由来は諸説ある。
sen.e: There are several views about the source of the name, 'Isuien' (Literally, 'Garden relying on water').
There are several views about the source of the name, 'Isuien' (Literally, 'Garden depending on water').
There are several views about the source of the name, 'Isuien' (Literally, 'Garden depending on water').

sen.j: 池が吉城川の水に依っているためという説や、然庭園内の池が草書体の水の形をしていることに由来するという説、杜甫の「名園緑碌水」の句に由来するなどの説があるが、はっきりしたことは分かっていない。
sen.e: They include a view that it derives from the fact the pond in the garden relies on the Yoshiki-gawa River, one that it comes from the fact that the pond is shaped like the letter 'Water' in the Sosho-tai (cursive style writing) and one that it was taken from a poem called 'Meien Ryokurokusui' by Toho (a Chinese poet), but it is not certain.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」「名園緑碌水」の読みは、字引、サイトでも見つからず不明です
sen.e: There are some opinions where the name is derived from, including from the fact that the pond water depends on the Yoshiki-gawa River, or the pond is shaped like the Chinese character 'Water' in the Sosho-tai (cursive style writing), or it was taken from a phrase 'Meien ha Ryokusui ni Yori' (The beautiful garden to go is spread along the green water) of a poem written by Toho (a Chinese poet), however, none of them is not certain.
sen.cmt: 「名園緑碌水」は確認できませんでしたが、奈良新聞のサイト（http://www.nara-np.co.jp/graph/gra050703_house.html）に基づき「名園依緑水」として、訳出しました。（漢詩の参考URL http://blog.goo.ne.jp/tiandaoxy/e/66f648d01ea612f918abfcf85e09ca72）
sen.e: There are some opinions where the name is derived from, including from the fact that the pond water depends on the Yoshiki-gawa River, or the pond is shaped like the Chinese character 'Water' in the Sosho-tai (cursive style writing), or it was taken from a phrase 'Meien ha Ryokusui ni Yori' (The beautiful garden to go is spread along the green water) of a poem written by Toho (a Chinese poet), however, none of them is not certain.
